Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study

1. Introduction
Project Description
The Denver Design District (DDD) General Development Plan (GDP) provides a long-range development
plan for the property bounded by Alameda Avenue to the north, Broadway to the east, and railroad tracks
to the south and west. The site provides direct access to the RTD Alameda light rail station which is
located just west of the property. In addition, the I-25 & Broadway station is located less than a quarter
mile south of the project. Figure 1 shows the project site. Due to the proximity of transit, the DDD is
planned as a dense, mixed-use development. As of July 2008, the full build-out of the GDP is proposed
to include approximately:

      ·   4,460 residential condominiums and townhomes
      ·   1,284,000 square feet of retail of which includes the Denver Design Center, large regional retail,
          and neighborhood supportive retail
      ·   241,000 square feet of educational center
      ·   2,488,000 square feet of office space
      ·   325 hotel rooms
      ·   89,000 square feet of light industrial of which exists today

Due to the large scale of the DDD and the existing development on portions of the site, the GDP consists
of three phases of the development. Phase 1 is expected to occur between 2009 and 2019 and will
consist of moderate levels of retail, residential, and office development around the Alameda light rail
station. Phase 2 is expected to occur between 2020 and 2029 and will primarily consist of developing the
southern section of the property with residential, retail, hotel, and office. The final phase of development
will focus on redeveloping the property near the corner of Alameda Avenue and Broadway and is
expected to occur between 2030 and 2050. The internal roadway infrastructure is proposed be
completed as necessary to support the development. Adjustments to the GDP lane uses have been
made and Appendix D shows the land use changes as of October 2008.

Figure 2 shows the DDD site plan as shown in the GDP. For planning purposes, the project is divided
into five sub-areas that are illustrated on the site plan. The sub-areas are roughly tied to the phasing of
the project. Phase 1 will consist of perimeter development in Sub-Areas 2 and 4. Phase 2 is expected to
include the completion of Sub-Areas 2 and 4 as well as the development of Sub-Area 5. Phase 3 is the
full build-out of the GDP plan and most of that development will be focused on Sub-Areas 1 and 3.

Study Objectives
This is the first traffic study to be conducted for the redevelopment of the DDD. It is intended to provide
the traffic analysis necessary for the City and County of Denver (CCD) staff to approve the GDP
submittal. As such, this will serve as the Master Transportation Study for the DDD. It is likely that more
detailed traffic analyses will be conducted as final development plans are approved for each Phase.

This study looks at two horizon years, 2020 and 2030. 2020 corresponds with the completion of Phase 1
and 2030 corresponds with the completion of Phase 2. General recommendations are made about
transportation improvements that will be necessary to support the levels of development proposed for
Phases 1 and 2.

Study Area

The study boundaries for the traffic analysis are Alameda Avenue to the north, Ohio Avenue to the south,
Lincoln Street to the east, and Kalamath Street to the west. The project team coordinated with City and
County of Denver (CCD) staff to determine the study boundaries. Based on the boundaries, the external
study intersections for the DDD TIS are:

    1.    Alameda Avenue & Kalamath Street
    2.    Alameda Avenue & Santa Fe Drive
    3.    Alameda Avenue & Cherokee Street
    4.    Alameda Avenue & Bannock Street
    5.    Alameda Avenue & Broadway
    6.    Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street
    7.    Lincoln Street & Dakota Avenue
    8.    Broadway & Dakota Avenue
    9.    Broadway & Virginia Avenue
    10.   Lincoln Street & Virginia Avenue
    11.   Lincoln Street & Center Avenue
    12.   Broadway & Center Avenue
    13.   Broadway & Exposition Avenue
    14.   Lincoln Street & Exposition Avenue
    15.   Lincoln Street & Ohio Avenue
    16.   Broadway & Ohio Avenue
    17.   Lincoln Street & Walsh Place

The internal street network will consist of a grid of public and private streets. Exposition Avenue, Center
Avenue, Virginia Avenue, Dakota Avenue, Cherokee Street, and Bannock Street are proposed to be
public streets maintained by the CCD. Detailed intersection analysis was not conducted at the private
street intersections. The internal study intersections are:

    18.   Exposition Avenue & Bannock Street
    19.   Center Avenue & Bannock Street
    20.   Virginia Avenue & Bannock Street
    21.   Virginia Avenue & Cherokee Street
    22.   Dakota Avenue & Cherokee Street
    23.   Dakota Avenue & Bannock Street

Figure 3 shows the locations of the study intersections.

                                                                       STUDY INTERSECTIONS AND ROADWAY NETWORK

Study Conditions
Both the AM peak hour and PM peak hour were included in the study to provide an evaluation of the
potential impact of the development during the peak weekday morning and evening periods with
commuter traffic. The following three conditions were analyzed in this study with the corresponding
volumes and network configurations as indicated. These study conditions were agreed upon with CCD
staff. The intersection analysis does not include a full build-out scenario of the GDP as this is not
anticipated to be complete until sometime beyond 2030 and traffic patterns may well change.

Existing Conditions

Analysis of the existing conditions in the study area were based on turning movement volumes collected
in January 2008 and the existing roadway, intersection geometry, and traffic control as observed in the
field. The existing conditions provide a baseline for the future analysis.

2020 Background Plus Project Conditions

Analysis of the 2020 background traffic plus project traffic was conducted to evaluate the anticipated
traffic impacts upon opening of Phase 1. The analysis of this condition was intended to represent the
volumes associated with Phase 1 of development and the proposed roadway network improvements.
The volumes included the existing counts with a growth rate (determined from the Broadway NEPA study)
applied out to the year 2020 along regional roadways, combined with the site-generated trips for Phase 1
land uses distributed regionally. The growth rates are defined in Section 3 of this document. Figure 3
illustrates the roadway network that is assumed to be in place by 2020 to support Phase 1 development.

2030 Background Plus Project Conditions

Analysis of the 2030 background traffic plus project traffic was conducted to evaluate the impact of the
project in 2030. This includes Phases 1 and 2 of development. The volumes included the existing counts
with a growth rate (determined from the Broadway NEPA study) applied out to the year 2030 along
regional roadways, combined with the site-generated trips for all land uses distributed regionally. Figure
3 illustrates that the entire public roadway network is assumed to be in place by 2030 as it is necessary to
support the development that will be completed by 2030.

Intersection Analysis Methodology
The traffic operations analysis addressed unsignalized and signalized intersection operations using the
procedures and methodologies contained in the Highway Capacity Manual 2000 (HCM), Transportation
Research Board, 2000 for the weekday AM peak hour and weekday PM peak hour traffic operations.
Study intersection operations were evaluated using level of service calculations as analyzed in the
Synchro software version 6.

Level of Service Criteria

To measure and describe the operational status of the local roadway network and corresponding
intersections, transportation engineers and planners commonly use a grading system called level of
service (LOS). LOS is a description of an intersection's operation, ranging from LOS A (indicating
free-flow traffic conditions with little or no delay) to LOS F (representing over-saturated conditions where
traffic flows exceed design capacity, resulting in long queues and delays).

Signalized Intersections

At signalized intersections, traffic conditions were evaluated using procedures and methodologies
contained in the Highway Capacity Manual 2000 (HCM), Transportation Research Board, 2000. The
operation analysis uses various intersection characteristics (such as traffic volumes, lane geometry, and



                                                                                                          6
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




signal phasing) to estimate the intersection's volume-to-capacity (v/c) ratio. For signalized intersections
the HCM defines the level of service as the average delay per vehicle for the overall intersection. Table 1
summarizes the relationship between delay and LOS for signalized intersections.

                          Table 1. Signalized Intersection Level of Service Criteria

                        Average Stopped Delay
Level of Service          (seconds/vehicle)                                         Description
       A                         < 10                  Very low delay. Most vehicles do not stop.
       B                       10.1 to 20              Generally good progression of vehicles. Slight delays.
       C                       20.1 to 35              Fair progression. Increased number of stopped vehicles.
       D                       35.1 to 55              Noticeable congestion. Large portion of vehicles stopped.
       E                       55.1 to 80              Poor progression. High delays and frequent cycle failure.
       F                         > 80                  Oversaturation. Forced flow. Extensive queuing.
 Source: Highway Capacity Manual (Transportation Research Board, 2000).


Unsignalized Intersections

For unsignalized (all-way stop-controlled and side-street stop-controlled) intersections, the Transportation
Research Board's 2000 Highway Capacity Manual methodology for unsignalized intersections was
utilized. With this methodology, operations are defined by the average control delay per vehicle
(measured in seconds) for each stop-controlled movement. The method incorporates delay associated
with deceleration, acceleration, stopping, and moving up in the queue. For all-way stop-controlled
intersections the HCM defines the level of service as the average delay per vehicle for the overall
intersection. For side street stop-controlled intersections, LOS is reported for the worst approach. In this
report the overall intersection delay and LOS is provided in parenthesis for informational purposes for
side street stop-controlled intersections. Table 2 summarizes the relationship between delay and LOS for
unsignalized intersections.


                         Table 2. Unsignalized Intersection Level of Service Criteria

                         Average Total Delay
Level of Service          (seconds/vehicle)                                         Description
       A                         < 10                  Little or no conflicting traffic for minor street approach.
       B                       10.1 to 15              Minor street approach begins to notice absence of available gaps.
                                                       Minor street approach begins experiencing delay for available
       C                       15.1 to 25
                                                       gaps.
                                                       Minor street approach experiences queuing due to a reduction in
       D                       25.1 to 35
                                                       available gaps.
       E                       35.1 to 50              Extensive minor street queuing due to insufficient gaps.
                                                       Insufficient gaps of suitable size to allow minor street traffic
       F                         > 50
                                                       demand to cross safely through a major traffic stream.
 Source: Highway Capacity Manual (Transportation Research Board, 2000).




Significance Criteria



                                                                                                                          7
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




The City and County of Denver has developed Interim Transportation Impact Study Guidelines that
include minimum acceptable levels of service and significant impact criteria. They are as follows:

         Minimum Acceptable Levels of Service: As a guideline the City and County of Denver
         desires to maintain a Level of Service D at all intersections as the minimum acceptable
         level of service. Due to the highly urbanized characteristics of Denver, it is recognized
         that there are locations where this minimum level of service does not currently exist.
         There are arterial and commercial corridors where the City and County of Denver will
         allow a Level of Service E to be the minimum.

         Significant Impact Criteria: A project is defined as significantly impacting a study
         intersection when one of the following criteria is satisfied:

         For Signalized Intersections:
         When the added project traffic causes an intersection to exceed the Level of Service
         standard; or
         When the background traffic conditions (without project traffic) exceeds the established
         level of service standards, and the project traffic causes more than a 2 percent increase
         in the intersection delay.

         For Unsignalized Intersections:
         Queuing of traffic to adjacent intersections would create impeded traffic flows; or excessive
         delays are determined to create potential safety problems.

Organization of Report
This report is divided into eight sections, including this introduction. Section 2 describes the existing
transportation conditions in the study area. Section 3 describes the methodologies used to forecast
future background traffic volumes. Section 4 describes the number of trips associated with the project for
each phase of development. Sections 5 and 6 present the results of the technical analysis for the 2020
and 2030 traffic conditions and the recommended traffic mitigation measures. Section 7 provides a
summary of the future transit, pedestrian, and bicycle circulation around the project site. Section 8
summarizes the conclusions of the study and the recommendations intended to address significant
impacts. Appendices to this report include details of the technical analysis.




                                                                                                         8
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




2. Existing Conditions
An assessment of the existing transportation system surrounding the project site was conducted. This
provides a clear picture of the system today and sets a baseline for future analysis.

Roadway System

Alameda Avenue, Broadway, and Lincoln Street are the principal arterials that provide direct access to
the project site. The site is conveniently located approximately two miles south of Downtown Denver.
Broadway and Lincoln Street provide direct access to downtown. In addition, the site is accessible to two
major north/south corridors in the Denver region; I-25 and Santa Fe Drive. Broadway and Lincoln Street
provide access to I-25 just south of the project. Santa Fe Drive is accessible via Alameda Avenue or
Mississippi Avenue (approximately one half mile south of the site).

Alameda is a four-lane east-west facility with auxiliary lanes as needed. Broadway is a four-lane
southbound one-way street with a fifth lane that provides right turn lanes. Lincoln Street is a three-lane
northbound one-way street with a fourth lane that provides right turn lanes. In addition, left turn lanes are
provided at major intersections along Lincoln Street. All other roadways surrounding the project site and
included in the analysis are two lane collectors.

Based upon field observations during the peak hours, the intersection of Lincoln Street and Ohio Avenue
operates as a two lane eastbound approach although the intersection is not striped for two lanes.

The intersections of Broadway and Walsh and Broadway and Ohio Avenue are both signalized and
operate as a single intersection with one controller. The analysis reflects the single intersection
operation.

Figure 4 shows the existing intersection lane configurations, control, and the AM and PM peak hour
volumes based on the January 2008 traffic counts. Appendix A includes the traffic count data.

Intersection Operations

Table 3 provides the results of the existing capacity analysis for both the AM and PM peak hours.
Currently, six of the study intersections operate at an LOS E or F during the AM and/or PM peak hour. As
shown in the table, the Alameda Avenue & Santa Fe Drive intersection operates at LOS E during the PM
peak hour. It is typical for major urban intersections to operate at or close to capacity (LOS E) during the
PM peak hour.

The side-streets of the following stop controlled intersections along Broadway and Lincoln Street are
shown to have at least one approach that operates at LOS F during one or both peak hours:

     ·    Lincoln Street & Dakota Avenue
     ·    Broadway & Dakota Avenue
     ·    Broadway & Exposition Avenue
     ·    Lincoln Street & Exposition Avenue
     ·    Lincoln Street & Ohio Avenue

Signals are planned at the Exposition Avenue and Ohio Avenue intersections based on the Broadway
NEPA study. Therefore, it is expected signals will be installed at these three locations once warrants are
met or as funding is available.




                                                                                                            9
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




There are no plans for signals at the Dakota Avenue intersections based on other studies. It should be
noted that the HCM analysis does not necessarily take into account the upstream signal and based on
field observations the delays for vehicles on Dakota Avenue are not as severe as those shown in the
HCM analysis due to the gaps created by the upstream signals.

Appendix B provides the LOS calculations for the existing conditions analysis.

November 2008




Existing Transit, Pedestrian, and Bicycle Circulation
Transit Facilities
The project site is accessible to two of the existing RTD light rail stations: I-25 & Broadway and Alameda.
The light rail stations serve the C, D, E, F, and H lines which provide service to and from downtown as
well as the southeast and southwest corridors. Light rail lines C and D travel to and from Littleton and
downtown Denver. Line C travels to and from Denver Union Station (DUS) and line D travels through the
Downtown Central Business District (CBD) and connects at the 30th and Downing Station. Light rail lines
E and F travel to and from Littleton and Denver. Line E travels to and from DUS, and line F travels
through the CBD. Light rail line H travels from Aurora and the CBD.

In addition to light rail each of these stations provides access to local and regional bus service.

The bus routes that serve the Alameda Station are as follows:

         ·   Route 3 Alameda Cross-town ­ Route 3 travels along Alameda Avenue between the
             Town Center at Aurora (Centerpoint Drive & Sable Boulevard) and Cold Spring Park-
             N-Ride. The route stops at Alameda Station where connections can be made to bus
             routes 52 and 79 as well as light rail lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 3 provides 5-15
             minute service throughout the day and half hour to hour service at night.

         ·   Route 4 Morrison Road ­ Route 4 travels along Alameda Avenue between Sheridan
             Boulevard at Morrison Road and Alameda Station. The route stops at Alameda
             Station where connections can be made to bus routes 52 and 79 as well as light rail
             lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 4 runs during morning and afternoon peak hours
             every 45 minutes.

         ·
                        rd
             Route 34 3 Avenue Industrial ­ Route 34 travels between the Excel Energy Center
                 rd
             at 3 Avenue and Osage Street along Cherokee Street, Alameda Avenue, then
             Broadway and Lincoln Street onto the I-25 & Broadway Station. The route stops at
             Alameda Avenue and Broadway/Lincoln Street where connections can be made to
             routes 3, 79, and 0. Route 34 provides three northbound runs in the morning and
             three southbound runs in the afternoon.

         ·   Route 52 West 52nd Avenue/South Pearl ­ Route 52 travels between Highway
             93/West 64th Avenue and Alameda Station. The route travels along Cherokee Street
             and terminates at Alameda Station where connections can be made to bus routes 3
             and 79 as well as light rail lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 52 provides 15 minute
             service during peak hours and half hour service during non-peak hours.

         ·   Route 79 East Florida ­ Route 79 travels between Alameda Station and Nine Mile
             Station. The route runs along Alameda Avenue east of Cherokee Street and
             terminates at Alameda Station where connections can be made to bus routes 3 and
             52 as well as light rail lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 79 provides half hour service
             during peak hours and hourly service during non-peak hours.

         ·   Route 0 South Broadway ­ Route 0 travels along Broadway between Downtown
             Denver and Highlands Ranch Town Center. The route stops at Alameda Avenue
             where connections can be made to routes 3, 34, and 79. This stop is about a half
             mile from the Alameda Station where connections can be made to bus route 52 and
             light rail lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 0 provides 5-10 minute service between
             downtown and I-25 & Broadway Station, 15 minute service between downtown and
             Englewood Station, and 30 minute service between downtown and Highlands Ranch.




                                                                                                         13
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




         ·   Route 0Ltd South Broadway Limited ­ Route 0Ltd travels along Broadway between
             Downtown Denver and Southglenn in Littleton. The route stops at Alameda Avenue
             where connections can be made to routes 3, 34, and 79. This stop is about a half
             mile from the Alameda Station where connections can be made to bus route 52 and
             light rail lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 0Ltd provides 5-10 minute service during the
             am peak and half hour service during the pm peak. The 0Ltd does not run during
             other times of day.

         ·   Route P Parker/Denver ­ Route P travels from Parker to Denver, using Broadway
             and Lincoln Street to access Denver. The route stops at Alameda Avenue. Route P
             runs northbound seven times in the am peak and southbound seven times during the
             pm peak.

The bus routes that serve the I-25 & Broadway Station are as follows:

         ·   Route 0 South Broadway ­ Route 0 travels along Broadway between Downtown
             Denver and Highlands Ranch Town Center. The route stops at I-25 & Broadway
             Station where connections can be made to routes 11, 14, 34, and 6X as well as light
             rail lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 0 provides 5-10 minute service between downtown
             and I-25 & Broadway Station, 15 minute service between downtown and Englewood
             Station, and 30 minute service between downtown and Highlands Ranch.

         ·   Route 0Ltd South Broadway Limited ­ Route 0Ltd travels along Broadway between
             Downtown Denver and Southglenn in Littleton. The route stops at I-25 & Broadway
             Station where connections can be made to routes 11, 14, 34, and 6X as well as light
             rail lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 0Ltd provides 5-10 minute service during the am
             peak and half hour service during the pm peak. The 0Ltd does not run during other
             times of day.

         ·   Route 6X Cold Spring/I-25 & Broadway ­ Route 6X is an express route that travels
             between the Federal Center (at US 6 & Union Avenue) and I-25 & Broadway where
             connections can be made to routes 0, 0Ltd, 6X, 11, and 34 as well as light rail lines
             C, D, E, F, and H. The route provides four eastbound and three west bound trips in
             the morning as well as three eastbound and four westbound trips in the
             afternoon/evening.

         ·   Route 11 Mississippi Crosstown ­ Route 11 travels along Mississippi Avenue
             between the Town Center at Aurora (near I-225 & Alameda Avenue) and Lakewood
             Commons (near Alameda Avenue & Wadsworth Boulevard). The route stops at I-25
             & Broadway Station where connections can be made to routes 0, 0Ltd, 6X, 14, and
             34 as well as light rail lines C, D, E, F, and H. Route 11 provides 20 minute to half
             hour service all day with hourly service in the late evening.

         ·   Route 14 West Florida ­ Route 14 travels along Florida Avenue between the Federal
             Center (US 6 & Union Avenue) and I-25 & Broadway Station where connections can
             be made to routes 0, 0Ltd, 6X, 11, and 34 as well as light rail lines C, D, E, F, and H.
             The route provides half hour service for most of the day with select routes running the
             entire distance in the morning and afternoon and midday routes running from I-25 &
             Broadway Station to Wadsworth Boulevard.

         ·
                       rd
             Route 34 3 Avenue Industrial ­ Route 3 travels between the Excel Energy Center at
              rd
             3 Avenue and Osage Street and I-25 & Broadway Station where connections can
             be made to routes 0, 0Ltd, 6X, 11, and 14 as well as light rail lines C, D, E, F, and H.



                                                                                                        14
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




             Route 34 provides three northbound runs in the morning and three southbound runs
             in the afternoon.

Pedestrian Facilities
Sidewalks exist on Broadway and Alameda Avenue adjacent to the project. On Alameda Avenue from
Cherokee Street to the west sidewalk is only present on the north side of the street. The interior of the
site is mostly parking lots for the large format retail and offices. There are limited sidewalks throughout.
The focus is on automobile parking and circulation. The southern side of the site has very limited
pedestrian connection to the I-25 & Broadway Station.
Bicycle Facilities
Several Denver bike routes run near or through the project site and are summarized below.

    ·    Bike Route D7 ­ Route D7 travels north-south from Englewood to I-70 utilizing the Platte River
         Trail, Alameda Avenue, and Cherokee Street in the vicinity of the DDD. The sidewalk on
         Alameda Avenue is utilized as part of the bicycle route between Cherokee Street and the Platte
         River Trail.

    ·    Bike Route D14 ­ Route D14 travels east-west from Aurora to Lakewood through neighborhood
         streets in Denver. This route utilizes Alameda Avenue and Cherokee Street near the project site.
         Route D14 can be used to access the Cherry Creek Trail by taking Cherokee Street north from
         the site to 1st Avenue east to the trail.

    ·    Bike Route D16 ­ Route D16 travels from Quebec Street in east Denver to Lakewood via
         neighborhood streets through Denver. This route utilizes Virginia Avenue, Cherokee Street, and
         Alameda Avenue in the vicinity of the DDD. Route D16 can be used to access the Platte River
         Trail by taking Cherokee Street north from the site to Alameda Avenue east to the trail.

There are several bike racks at Alameda Station but none of the adjacent or through streets at the site
have dedicated bicycle lanes. The streets that are designated as bicycle routes are considered
neighborhood shared lane facilities without separate bicycle lanes. There is no bicycle connection
between Alameda Station and the I-25 & Broadway Station.




                                                                                                               15
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




3. Future Background Traffic
Future Background Traffic Projections
Background traffic projections were developed for horizon years 2020 and 2030. Based on discussions
with CCD staff and as shown the DRCOG model, it was determined that no background growth would be
applied to Alameda Avenue as it is currently operating under capacity constrained conditions. The
background growth rate for the remaining intersections along Broadway and Lincoln Street was
determined from the Broadway NEPA study. Based upon the previous study, a 2% growth per year was
applied to the existing traffic volumes to determine the background 2020 and 2030 volumes. The
volumes used for Santa Fe and Kalamath were based upon the Valley Highway EIS volumes.

Figure 5 shows the projected 2020 background peak hour volumes at each of the study intersections.
Figure 6 provides the 2030 background peak hour volumes. These volumes provide the baseline
conditions for comparative purposes with the total traffic projections including the project.

Future Roadway System

As discussed in Section 3, signals are planned for the following three intersections based on the
Broadway NEPA study:

     ·    Broadway & Exposition Avenue
     ·    Lincoln Street & Exposition Avenue
     ·    Lincoln Street & Ohio Avenue

As a result, these intersections are assumed to be signalized for both the 2020 and 2030 analysis.

The improvements shown in the Valley Highway EIS were not assumed to be in place for either the 2020
or 2030 analysis as there is currently no funding in place to implement the changes recommended in the
EIS.

No other planned roadway improvement projects were identified in the immediate vicinity of the DDD
project. Therefore, the only other changes to the roadway network included in the analysis are the
internal roadways that will be built to support the development. Figure 3 illustrates the additional
roadway segments that will be built in 2020 and 2030. In general, the street network will be complete
from Virginia Avenue north in 2020. The southern segments of the grid will be added by 2030 to
complete the internal street network.

4. Project Traffic
Trip Generation
The vehicle trips associated with the DDD project were calculated using the ITE Trip Generation Manual,
Seventh Edition and subsequently adjusted to reflect the unique trip generation characteristics of a transit
oriented development. Trip generation forecasts were developed for Phase 1 (2020), Phase 2 (2030),
and full build-out of the GDP. Between the submittal of the draft TIS and the final TIS the land uses
proposed in the GDP changed. A sensitivity analysis was completed to determine the effect on the
reports conclusions and recommendations. The analysis indicated the overall conclusions to this report
will not change. Appendix D contains the October 2008 land use information and the resulting sensitivity
analysis.

The ITE methodology consists of choosing an appropriate independent variable for each land use for a
particular time of day. The value of the independent variable is multiplied by a weighted average rate or
inserted into a regression equation to calculate the trips generated by each land use. The ITE land uses
assumed for the DDD GDP were Specialty Retail (814), Shopping Center (820), Furniture Store (890),
High-Rise Residential Condominium/Townhouse (232), General Office Building (710), Hotel (310), Junior
College (540), and Light Industrial (110). Table 4 shows the variables used to calculate trip generation
for Phase 1 development.



                                       Table 4. Phase 1 (2020) Trip Generation Variables

             Land Use                ITE Code          Independent                      Regression Equation/Average Rate
                                                         Variable                   Daily            AM                PM
    Sub-Area 2
     Residential                         232         90 dwelling units        Average Rate             Average Rate             Average Rate
     Neighborhood Retail                 814            30,000 sf             Average Rate             Average Rate             Average Rate
     Regional Retail                     820             31,000 sf            Average Rate             Average Rate             Average Rate
     Office                              710            769,000 sf            Regression Eq            Regression Eq            Regression Eq
    Sub-Area 4
     Residential                         232        210 dwelling units         Average Rate            Average Rate              Average Rate
1
    AM Peak Hour of Adjacent Street Traffic not available for Specialty Retail Center (ITE Code 814). Average Rate calculated from the ratio of the
     average rate for the AM Peak Hour of Generator to that of the PM Peak Hour of Generator multiplied to the average rate of the PM Peak Hour of
     Adjacent Street Traffic. The entering and exiting percentages for the AM Peak Hour of Generator were flipped as is the case for the PM Peak Hour
     of Generator.




                                                                                                                                                    19
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008

at the time of the GDP submittal.

Trip Reduction

The DDD development is located within a half-mile walk of the RTD Alameda or I-25 & Broadway transit
stations. The proximity to light rail and bus access allows for a vehicular trip reduction from the raw ITE
trip generation rates, since these rates assume a suburban setting and all trips generated are vehicular
trips. The ITE Trip Generation Handbook does not have a procedure that accounts for vehicular trip
reduction based on the proximity to light rail stations. The City's proposed infrastructure improvements
will also provide better pedestrian and bicycle connectivity between the two stations.




                                                                                                                        23
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




Fehr & Peers developed a trip reduction procedure for proximity to transit for the Belleview Station TOD
Master Transportation Study/Traffic Impact Study (2005) in Denver. This methodology has been refined
and approved by City and County of Denver Transportation staff. This methodology takes into account
the most up to date research for trips generated within a TOD.

This approach, which is referred to as the Mixed-Use Development (MXD)/Transit-Oriented Development
(TOD) Method, builds upon the internal capture approach described for Mixed-Use projects in the ITE
Manual. The internal capture rates alone, however, do not explicitly reflect the presence of transit
facilities. In addition, empirical data have shown that the share of transit use in TODs varies greatly
between work and non-work trips, so establishing a single percentage based approach is problematic.
The MXD/TOD Method further refines trip generation by accounting for the transit facilities by analyzing
trip purpose and mode split. After determining the percent of daily and peak hour trips that are work-
related and non-work-related, mode split factors were applied to differentiate between driving trips and
trips by other modes for work and non-work trip purpose.

Table 10 shows the factors that were used to determine the number of work versus non-work related trips
for the DDD TOD development. These results are based on Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO)
travel surveys and were obtained from DRCOG.


                                      Table 10. Work/Non-Work Trip Purpose

                                                Work                                     Non-Work
      Land Use
                               Peak Hour                     Daily              Peak Hour           Daily
 Residential                        70%                       21%                 30%               79%
 Office                             80%                       18%                 20%               82%
 Hotel                              20%                       25%                 80%               75%
 Retail                             10%                       20%                 90%               80%
 Source: DRCOG; MTC; NPTS; Fehr & Peers 2005


The work and non-work related trips provide a basis for estimating mode split. Information sources for
mode split will vary, and this report's factors were based upon Robert Cervero's extensive research in
California. Table 11 provides the mode split factors for the DDD development. Trips not categorized as
"drive" are by other modes, such as bicycle, pedestrian, fixed-route transit, and light rail.


                                    Table 11. Drive Mode Split by Trip Purpose

                                                Work                                     Non-Work
      Land Use                 Peak Hour                     Daily              Peak Hour           Daily
                                 Drive                       Drive                Drive             Drive
 Hotel                            57.7%                      57.7%               97.6%              97.6%
 Office                           77.8%                      77.8%               39.5%              39.5%
 Residential                      71.7%                      71.7%               87.1%              87.1%
 Retail                           77.8%                      77.8%               68.3%              68.3%
 Source: Travel Characteristics of Transit-Oriented Development In California




                                                                                                            24
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




The mode split factors were applied to the "raw" ITE trip generation results to determine the number of
vehicle trips for each type of development. Tables 12-14 show the results of applying the MXD/TOD
Method to the residential, office, and hotel land uses.

The MXD/TOD Method has been developed for residential, regional destination retail, office, and hotel
land uses. A portion of the retail proposed in the DDD GDP is planned to be neighborhood supporting
(specialty) retail not regional destination retail. Therefore, the MXD/TOD Method of trip reduction cannot
be applied to all retail proposed for the development. There is not specific research regarding
neighborhood supporting retail so, upon direction from the City of Denver, the reduction rate for the
specialty retail was dropped below that of regional destination retail. The ITE internal capture
methodology was used to calculate the trip reduction for the neighborhood supportive portion of the DDD
retail. The ITE methodology accounts for the trip reduction that the specialty retail will experience as a
result of being located in a mixed-use development. However, the internal capture methodology does not
account for any additional reduction that would occur from the specialty retail being located within a half
mile of a light rail transit station. Based on the ITE internal capture methodology, a 13% trip reduction
was taken for the specialty retail during the AM and PM peak hours and a 13.5% reduction was taken for
the daily specialty retail trip generation. Tables 12-14 provide the reduced (adjusted) trips generated for
the neighborhood supportive retail.


                               Table 12. Phase 1 (2020) Total Vehicle Trips (Adjusted)

                                                         AM Peak Hour Trips                                 PM Peak Hour Trips
         Land Use             Daily Trips
                                                    In              Out            Total              In           Out       Total
 Sub-Area 2
   Residential                     315              4                19             23                16           10            26
   Neighborhood Retail            1,150            50                46             96                31           40            71
   Regional Retail                2,227            14                9              23                96           104           200
   Office                         2,977            592               81             673              112           547           659
 Sub-Total                        6,669            660              155             815              255           701           956
 Sub-Area 4
  Residential                      736              10              44               54               38            23           61
 Total                           7,405             670             199              869              293           724       1,017
  Source: ITE Trip Generation Manual, 7th Edition, MXD/TOD Trip Reduction Methodology; Fehr & Peers, 2008

November 2008




Trip Distribution

Trip distribution was based upon existing traffic patterns and further refined while meeting with the
surrounding neighborhood groups. Figure 7 shows the external trip distribution.

In general, 40% of the traffic is traveling to/from the north. Most of this traffic will use the
Broadway/Lincoln Street corridor to access downtown. 20% of the traffic is traveling on Alameda Avenue
to/from the west. Some of this traffic will access I-25 from Alameda but there is not a full interchange at
Alameda Avenue. A total of 15% of the traffic is accessing the site from the east, with the majority of this
traffic using Alameda Avenue. The remaining 25% of the traffic is traveling to/from the south on
Broadway. This 25% includes vehicles accessing I-25 from Broadway.

Project Trips

Project trips were determined by combining project generated trips, shown in Tables 12 & 13, with the
distribution patterns shown in Figure 7. The project trips were also distributed through the internal study
intersections.

Figure 8 provides peak hour project-only traffic volumes at the study intersections for the 2020 analysis.
Figure 9 provides the project-only traffic volumes at the study intersections for the 2030 analysis.

Total Site Generated Traffic

Due to the phased development, the total site generated traffic will be a combination of existing traffic and
additional traffic generated from the new development. As the project progresses to Phase 2 and
beyond, some of the existing land uses will be replaced with new development. The assumptions used
for the total site generated traffic for the analysis are described below and summarized in Table 15.

It was assumed that all of the existing development would remain in Phase 1. To account for the traffic
that is generated by the existing development, counts were obtained in January 2008 at the driveways
associated with the site. The counts provided a baseline for the existing site generated trips. The trips
were assumed to stay in place until Phase 2 development begins to replace existing uses with new uses.
Therefore, the total site generated traffic assumed for 2020 was the Phase 1 trip generation (Table 12)
plus all existing trips.

For Phase 2, it was assumed that the southern section of the project site would be redeveloped.
Therefore, all existing land uses south of Virginia Avenue would be replaced with new development
except for the Design Center. However, the Design Center was included in the trip generation
calculations (Table 13) so all existing traffic counts south of Virginia Avenue were credited and replaced
with the volumes generated by Phase 2 of the GDP. It was assumed that all existing development north
of Virginia Avenue would still be operational in 2030 so no existing counts were removed from the
northern site access points.

The trip generation for the full GDP build-out includes all land uses shown in the final development plan
(Table 14). This includes existing uses that will remain when the project is complete such as the light
industrial located in the northwest corner of the site and the Design Center. Since the trip generation
methodology was applied to all future land uses, all existing traffic counts from the site access points
would need to be removed for an analysis of the full GDP.

Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008

5. Phase 1 (2020) Traffic Operations Analysis
The 2020 analysis presented in this section is used to determine the projected operations of the
surrounding roadway network with the completion of Phase 1 of the DDD GDP.

Total Traffic Projections

The project generated traffic shown in Figure 8 was added to the background traffic volumes shown in
Figure 5. As discussed in Section 4, it was assumed that all existing traffic generated by the site would
remain for the Phase 1 analysis. Figure 10 shows the total traffic used in the Phase 1 (2020) analysis as
well as the intersection lane configurations and control.

2020 Roadway Network

As discussed in Section 3, the 2020 analysis includes updates to the roadway network that were
proposed as part of the Broadway NEPA study. The improvements include signals at Ohio Avenue &
Lincoln Street, Exposition Avenue & Lincoln Street, and Exposition Avenue & Broadway.

It was assumed that the traffic signal timing plans would be updated by 2020. The existing cycle lengths
were used for the 2020 analysis. Cycle lengths for the new signals were determined from the Broadway
NEPA analysis.

Internal roadways are necessary to support the Phase 1 development. By 2020 Dakota Avenue and
Virginia Avenue is expected to be extended west to connect to Cherokee Street. In addition, Bannock
Street is expected to be improved during Phase 1 of the DDD GDP. These are all proposed to be public
streets. The new intersections will require the following stop control:

    20.   Virginia Avenue & Bannock Street ­ side-street stop control on Bannock Street
    21.   Virginia Avenue & Cherokee Street ­ side-street stop control on Virginia Avenue
    22.   Dakota Avenue & Cherokee Street ­ side-street stop control on Dakota Avenue
    23.   Dakota Avenue & Bannock Street ­ side-street stop control on Dakota Avenue

Figure 11 shows the roadway network assumed to be in place for the 2020 analysis.

Intersection Capacity Analysis

Table 16 shows the Phase 1 analysis results for the 2020 background and 2020 with project traffic
conditions. The results are presented for all external intersections as well as the internal intersections
that are expected to be in place by 2020. Appendix B provides the LOS analysis worksheets.

Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




The following intersections are expected to operate at a LOS E or F in the AM and/or PM peak hour
under both the 2020 background and with project scenarios.

      ·   Alameda Avenue & Kalamath Street
      ·   Alameda Avenue & Santa Fe Drive
      ·   Dakota Avenue & Lincoln Street
      ·   Dakota Avenue & Broadway

Without the improvements shown in the Valley Highway EIS, the Kalamath Street and Santa Fe Drive
intersections with Alameda Avenue will operate at or near capacity (LOS E) in the PM peak hour by 2020.
Phase 1 of the DDD has very little impact on these intersections.

Dakota Avenue is shown to experience high levels of delay at Broadway and Lincoln Street in both the
AM and PM peak hour. As discussed in Section 2, the HCM analysis does not take into account the
upstream signals so there may be more acceptable gaps for turns from Dakota Avenue and the delay
may not be as significant as the LOS results indicate. In addition, the LOS results show that there is
available capacity at the Virginia Avenue and Center Avenue signals. Drivers are likely to divert to the
signalized intersections if they experience high levels of delay at the Dakota Avenue intersections. It is
recommended that this location be monitored as the development occurs and a full signal warrant study,
including a pedestrian warrant be conducted if these intersections are observed to operate with high
levels of delay or as pedestrian traffic increases in the area. A preliminary signal warrant analysis based
upon projected traffic volumes for this location is provided below.

Phase 1 is shown to degrade the LOS at Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street from a D to an E in the AM
peak hour. In order to mitigate this intersection back to an LOS D in the AM peak hour, a third westbound
through lane would need to be added. The addition of a third westbound lane would require the
acquisition of Right-of-Way and could have a negative impact on the pedestrian environment. Therefore,
due to the negative impact on the pedestrian environment, this mitigation measure is not recommended.
Due to the urban nature of this intersection, it is reasonable to accept that this intersection will operate at
a LOS E during the AM peak hour. A corridor study for Alameda Avenue would be the best approach for
determining appropriate mitigation measures for this intersection in the future.

Signal Warrant Analysis
A preliminary signal warrant analysis was performed on the two side-street stop-controlled intersections
that operated with high levels of delay: Dakota Avenue & Lincoln Street and Dakota Avenue & Broadway.
The warrants identified in the Federal Highway Administration's Manual on Uniform Traffic Control
Devices (MUTCD) were used for the analysis. The Peak Hour Volume Warrant and other relevant factors
were considered in evaluating the addition of signal operations at these intersections.

Peak Hour Warrant

The Peak Hour Warrant, which compares the volumes at an intersection during the peak hour of
operation to the warrant requirements for the major street and minor street traffic, was evaluated for the
2020 background plus project AM and PM peak hours. All of the roadways within the study area were
assumed to be signed with speed limits of 40 mph or less and were considered to be located within an
urban setting. The corresponding warrant requirements for such conditions were applied in conducting
the signal warrant analysis.

Neither of the intersections analyzed meet the Peak Hour Warrant during the AM peak hour. Both
intersections satisfy the Peak Hour Warrant during the PM peak hour. MUTCD requires at least two
warrants be met prior to installing a signal. It is reasonable to believe that neither the four hour nor the
eight hour warrants would be met since both peak hours were not met. Appendix C includes the signal



                                                                                                             37
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




warrant analysis worksheets. Further analyses were completed at the intersections to determine a final
intersection control recommendation for 2020.

Other Relevant Factors

Other factors were considered when determining if signals are necessary at the Dakota Avenue
intersections in 2020.

    ·    There are upstream signals at Alameda Ave and Virginia Ave that would create gaps at
         Dakota Ave that are not necessarily accounted for in the HCM intersection analysis. The
         delay at these intersections may not be as significant as the results suggest due to the
         gaps created by the upstream signals.

    ·    There is available capacity at the Virginia Ave and Center Ave intersections with
         Broadway/Lincoln St that are both signalized. It is reasonable to assume that vehicles
         will divert from Dakota Ave if delays are significant at the Broadway/Lincoln St
         intersections to these other roadways with signals.

Due to the results of the signal warrant analyses, the Broadway & Dakota Ave and Lincoln St & Dakota
Ave intersections are not recommended to be signalized during Phase 1.

This signal warrant analysis is intended to examine the general correlation between the planned level of
future development and the need to install new traffic signals. It estimates future development-generated
traffic compared against a sub-set of the standard traffic signal warrants recommended in the MUTCD
and associated State guidelines. This analysis should not serve as the only basis for deciding whether
and when to install a signal. To reach such a decision, the full set of warrants should be investigated
based on field-measured, rather than forecast, traffic data and a thorough study of traffic and roadway
conditions by an experienced engineer. Furthermore, the decision to install a signal should not be based
solely upon the warrants, since the installation of signals can lead to certain types of collisions.

Mitigation Measures

Based on the discussion of the intersections that operate below an LOS D in the Intersection Capacity
Analysis section and the results of the preliminary signal warrant analyses, no mitigation measures are
recommended for Phase 1 of the GDP.




                                                                                                          38
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




6. Phase 2 (2030) Traffic Operations Analysis
The 2030 analysis presented in this section is used to determine the projected operations of the
surrounding roadway network with the completion of Phase 2 of the DDD GDP.

Total Traffic Projections

The project generated traffic shown in Figure 9 was added to the background traffic volumes shown in
Figure 6. As discussed Section 4, it was assumed that the area south of Virginia Avenue would be
redeveloped and the existing traffic replaced with new traffic. Therefore, the existing traffic volumes were
credited in the 2030 analysis. Figure 12 shows the total traffic used in the Phase 2 (2030) analysis as
well as the intersection lane configurations and control.

2030 Roadway Network

The 2030 analysis assumes the same external roadway network as was used in the 2020 analysis. It
was assumed that the traffic signal timing plans would be updated between 2020 and 2030. The
individual intersection splits were optimized and offsets were optimized along the Alameda Avenue,
Broadway, and Lincoln Street corridors. The 2020 cycle lengths were used for the 2030 analysis.

The internal roadway network is proposed to continue to expand to support Phase 2 of the development.
Bannock Street is proposed to be extended to the south beyond Exposition Avenue. Exposition Avenue
is proposed to be extended west to Bannock Street. Both Bannock Street and Exposition Avenue are
planned to be public streets. The new intersections will require the following stop control:

    18. Exposition Avenue & Bannock Street ­ side-street stop control on Exposition Avenue
    19. Center Avenue & Bannock Street ­ side-street stop control on Center Avenue

Figure 13 shows the roadway network assumed to be in place for the 2030 analysis.

Intersection Capacity Analysis

Table 17 shows the Phase 2 analysis results for the 2030 background and 2030 with project traffic
conditions. The results are presented for all external and public internal intersection. Appendix B
provides the LOS analysis worksheets.

                                                                                     A.M.
                                                            SIDE-STREET                          (< 1)           (A)           (9)           (A)
   18.            EXPOSITION & BANNOCK
                                                           STOP CONTROL                           <1              A            9              A

   19.               CENTER & BANNOCK
