                                                                                                  (8)            (A)        (> 100)          (F)
Notes:
         1   The Signalized intersection LOS and delay results are reported for the overall intersection. The unsignalized results are reported for
             the worst case approach, with the overall intersection results provided in parenthesis for informational purposes.
         2   The delay is reported as the average delay per vehicle in seconds.




                                                                                                                                                                                 42
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




The thirteen intersections shown below are expected to operate below a LOS D in the AM and/or PM
peak hours:

    ·    Alameda Avenue & Kalamath Street
    ·    Alameda Avenue & Santa Fe Drive
    ·    Alameda Avenue & Bannock Street
    ·    Alameda Avenue & Broadway
    ·    Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street
    ·    Dakota Avenue & Lincoln Street
    ·    Dakota Avenue & Broadway
    ·    Virginia Avenue & Lincoln Street
    ·    Center Avenue & Lincoln Street
    ·    Center Avenue & Broadway
    ·    Exposition Avenue & Broadway
    ·    Virginia Avenue & Bannock Street
    ·    Dakota Avenue & Bannock Street

Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street is expected to operate at a LOS F in the AM peak hour in 2030 under
both the background and with project scenarios. Similar to the Phase 1 analysis, in order to mitigate this
intersection back to a LOS D, a third westbound through lane plus a fourth northbound through would
need to be added. The addition of a third westbound lane would require the acquisition of Right-of-Way
and would have a negative impact on the pedestrian environment. The addition of a fourth northbound
through lane would negatively impact the bus transit operation on Lincoln Street. Due to the negative
impacts on right-of-way, pedestrians, and transit, these mitigation measures are not recommended. It is
recommended that corridor studies be conducted for Alameda Avenue and Lincoln Street to determine
appropriate mitigation measures for this location.

Alameda Avenue & Broadway is expected to operate with an average delay of 57 seconds (LOS E) in the
PM peak hour with Phase 2 of the DDD. 55 seconds of delay is the cut-off point between LOS D and E.
Therefore, mitigation measures are not recommended at this intersection since it is shown to operate so
close to an LOS D and any mitigation measures would likely require right-of-way and would negatively
impact the pedestrian environment. A LOS E is typical in urban areas and considered acceptable. In
addition, with the implementation of mitigation measures (discussed in the following sections) for
surrounding intersections, this intersection is shown to operate at a LOS D.

Mitigation measures for the remaining eleven intersections are described in the following sections.
Preliminary signal warrant analysis based upon project peak hour traffic was performed for the four side-
street stop control intersections when considering mitigation measures and is described below.

Signal Warrant Analysis
A preliminary signal warrant analysis was performed on the four side-street stop-controlled intersections
that operated with high levels of delay: Dakota Avenue & Lincoln Street, Dakota Avenue & Broadway,
Virginia Avenue & Bannock Street, and Dakota Avenue & Bannock Street. The warrants identified in the
Federal Highway Administration's Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) were used for the
analysis. The Peak Hour Volume Warrant and other relevant factors were considered in evaluating the
addition of signal operations at these intersections.

Peak Hour Warrant

The Peak Hour Warrant, which compares the volumes at an intersection during the peak hour of
operation to the warrant requirements for the major street and minor street traffic, was evaluated for the



                                                                                                         43
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




2030 background plus project AM and PM peak hours. All of the roadways within the study area were
assumed to be signed with speed limits of 40 mph or less and were considered to be located within an
urban setting. The corresponding warrant requirements for such conditions were applied in conducting
the signal warrant analysis.

All four of the intersections satisfy the Peak Hour Warrant during the PM peak hour. In addition, the
internal intersections on Bannock Street also satisfy the Peak Hour Warrant during the AM peak hour.
The signals on Dakota Avenue do not meet the Peak Hour Warrant during the AM peak hour. Appendix
C includes the signal warrant analysis worksheets.

Based on the peak hour warrant analysis, it is recommended that the two intersections on Bannock Street
be signalized with the build-out of Phase 2. Further analyses were completed at the Dakota Avenue
intersections to determine final intersection control recommendations for 2030.

Other Relevant Factors

Other factors were considered when determining if signals are necessary at the Dakota Avenue
intersections in 2030.

    ·    The delay for vehicles on Dakota Avenue will continue to increase as the volumes on
         Broadway and Lincoln Street increase. In addition, the Phase 2 build-out adds additional
         volume onto Dakota Avenue. There is less available capacity at the Virginia Avenue
         signals. If the vehicles exiting the site via Dakota Avenue were to divert to Virginia
         Avenue queue problems could result that would block internal intersections along Virginia
         Avenue.

    ·    Signal progression along Broadway and Lincoln Street would not be negatively impacted
         by the addition of signals on Dakota Avenue.

    ·    Pedestrian traffic in the area is expected to increase and a signal at Dakota Avenue plus
         crosswalks will convey pedestrian traffic across the busy roadways.

    ·    A signal is being recommended at the internal intersection of Dakota Avenue & Bannock
         Street. This intersection meets the peak hour warrant in both peak hours and is
         necessary for internal site circulation with the amount of development being proposed in
         Phase 2 of the GDP. It is recommended that the intersection be signalized at the same
         time as the Dakota Avenue intersections at Broadway and Lincoln Street.

The results of the signal warrant analyses suggest that all four intersections should be signalized with the
build-out of Phase 2 of the GDP.

This signal warrant analysis is intended to examine the general correlation between the planned level of
future development and the need to install new traffic signals. It estimates future development-generated
traffic compared against a sub-set of the standard traffic signal warrants recommended in the MUTCD
and associated State guidelines. This analysis should not serve as the only basis for deciding whether
and when to install a signal. To reach such a decision, the full set of warrants should be investigated
based on field-measured, rather than forecast, traffic data and a thorough study of traffic and roadway
conditions by an experienced engineer. Furthermore, the decision to install a signal should not be based
solely upon the warrants, since the installation of signals can lead to certain types of collisions.




                                                                                                         44
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




Mitigation Measures
Mitigation measures are described below for all the intersections that operate with high levels of delay
except for Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street and Alameda Avenue & Broadway. As discussed above,
mitigation measures for these two intersections should be determined by corridor studies.

Table 17 presents the final mitigated LOS results. Figure 12 presents the mitigated lane geometries and
intersection control. With the mitigation measures described below, all of the study intersections operate
at LOS D or better in both peak hours.

Alameda Avenue & Kalamath Street. This intersection is expected to operate at a LOS E in the PM peak
hour in 2030 both with and without the project. The Valley Highway Final EIS was referenced in order to
determine possible mitigation measures at this intersection. Consistent with the Valley Highway EIS, it is
recommended that a third westbound through lane be added to this intersection. However, the preferred
alternative for the Valley Highway EIS shows that one of the existing westbound left turn lanes should be
converted to the additional through lane. Based on the projected number of left turning vehicles onto
Kalamath Street, this is not recommended. The final westbound configuration should be two left turn
lanes and three through lanes.

Alameda Avenue & Santa Fe Drive. This intersection is expected to operate at an LOS F in the PM peak
hour with the addition of Phase 2 development. The Valley Highway Final EIS was referenced in order to
determine possible mitigation measures at this intersection. The recommended mitigation measure is to
add a third westbound through lane. This is consistent with the 2025 Lane Geometry for the Preferred
Alternative shown in the Valley Highway Final EIS.

Alameda Avenue & Bannock Street. With the additional project traffic, this intersection is expected to
operate at LOS E and D in the AM and PM peak hour respectively. The critical movement at this
intersection is the westbound left turns heading to the project site. This is currently a permitted only left
movement. It is recommended that the westbound left phase be changed from permitted only to
protected/permitted. With the protected/permitted westbound lefts, the intersection will operate at LOS C
or better during both peak hours.

Dakota Avenue & Lincoln Street. The vehicles on Dakota Avenue experience high levels of delay at this
intersection. Based on the discussion in the Signal Warrant Analysis section, it is recommended that this
location be signalized with the completion of Phase 2 and after a full signal warrant analysis has been
conducted.

Dakota Avenue & Broadway. The vehicles on Dakota Avenue experience high levels of delay at this
intersection. Based on the discussion in the Signal Warrant Analysis section, it is recommended that this
location be signalized with the completion of Phase 2 and after a full signal warrant analysis has been
conducted. In addition, the eastbound right turn lane needs to be separated from the through lane. This
is a minor striping change that should be accommodated within the existing right-of-way.

Virginia Avenue & Lincoln Street. With the addition of Phase 2 of the DDD, this intersection is expected
to operate at a LOS E in the AM peak hour. Without the project, this intersection would operate at a LOS
C. The additional westbound traffic traveling to the project site causes the operations to decrease. A
minor striping change is recommended to mitigate this intersection to an acceptable LOS with the project.
It is recommended that the westbound approach be re-striped to include a through lane and a right lane
opposed to one shared lane. Preliminary observations of this intersection suggest that there is available
right-of-way to make this change. With the dedicated westbound right turn lane, this intersection should
operate at LOS C during both peak hours.

Center Avenue & Lincoln Street. With the addition of Phase 2 traffic, this intersection is expected to
operate at a LOS E in the AM peak hour. The additional eastbound traffic traveling from the project site
and making a left turn onto Lincoln Street causes the decrease in operations. Therefore, it is


                                                                                                            45
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




recommended that the eastbound approach be re-striped to include a through lane and a dedicated left
turn lane. Preliminary observations of this intersection suggest that no additional right-of-way would be
required to implement this mitigation measure. With the dedicated eastbound left turn lane, this
intersection should operate at a LOS C or better in both peak hours.

Center Avenue & Broadway. This intersection is expected to operate at a LOS F in the PM peak hour
with the addition of Phase 2 of the DDD. The operations at this intersection are caused by the eastbound
and westbound traffic traveling to and from the project site along Center Avenue. By separating the
eastbound right turns from the eastbound through lane and the westbound left turns from the westbound
through lane, this intersection will operate at a LOS C or better during both peak hours. Therefore, it is
recommended that the eastbound and westbound approaches to this intersection be re-striped to provide
dedicated turn lanes. Preliminary observations of this intersection suggest that no additional right-of-way
would need to be acquired to make these changes.

Exposition Avenue & Broadway. This intersection is expected to operate at a LOS E in the PM peak hour
with the addition of Phase 2 of the DDD. To operate at an acceptable LOS with Phase 2 of the DDD, two
mitigation measures are recommended. First, the eastbound right turn lane should be separated from the
eastbound through lane to accommodate additional traffic traveling from the project site. The eastbound
approach to this intersection will be constructed as part of the DDD. Therefore, it should be constructed
with a dedicated right turn lane.

In addition, the southbound traffic on Broadway is heavy enough that the left turn movement should be
pulled out of the through travel lanes. It is likely that the intersection already operates with a left turn lane
as the east most lane on Broadway is wide to accommodate on-street parking. However, based on the
volumes at this intersection, a left turn lane should be added with striping to ensure that the southbound
through movement does not experience unnecessary delay.

Virginia Avenue & Bannock Street. With the addition of Phase 2 development, the peak hour volumes at
this intersection exceed the volumes that can be served with side-street stop control. In addition, this
intersection does not meet the all-way stop control guidelines presented in the Federal Highway
Administration's Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). Therefore, it is recommended that
this location be signalized with the completion of Phase 2 and after a full signal warrant analysis has been
conducted. A discussion of the peak hour signal warrant at this intersection is presented in the Signal
Warrant Analysis section above.

Dakota Avenue & Bannock Street. With the addition of Phase 2 development, the peak hour volumes at
this intersection exceed the volumes that can be served with side-street stop control. In addition, this
intersection does not meet the all-way stop control guidelines presented in the Federal Highway
Administration's Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). Therefore, it is recommended that
this location be signalized with the completion of Phase 2 and after a full signal warrant analysis has been
conducted. A discussion of the peak hour signal warrant at this intersection is presented in the Signal
Warrant Analysis section above.




                                                                                                               46
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




7. Future Transit, Pedestrian, and Bicycle Circulation
Transit, pedestrian, and bicycle circulation will be vital as the DDD develops due to the proximity to the
Alameda and I-25 Broadway light rail stations. The following sections describe changes to the alternative
mode systems that are likely to occur in the future as the DDD develops and the Alameda Station plan is
implemented.

Transit Facilities
It is likely that the number of buses serving the Alameda and I-25 & Broadway Stations will increase.
Therefore, bus circulation is an important consideration in the street layout of the DDD. The GDP shows
busses circulating on Cherokee Street then traveling east on Virginia Avenue for a half block then north to
Alaska Place and back to Cherokee Street. Upon meeting with RTD service planners and engineers and
the City and County of Denver, four to five bus bays are being planned at Alameda Station.

RTD anticipates the following two changes to occur at the Alameda and I-25 & Broadway light rail stations
in the near future. 1. The platforms will be extended to accommodate 4-car trains. 2. The stations will be
modified to accommodate a third track west of the existing tracks. The third track is being planned for at
the Cherokee Development site, south of the I-25 & Broadway Station, and is planned to continue north of
the Alameda Station.

Pedestrian Facilities
Three pedestrian/bicycle bridges are being planned in the vicinity of the DDD to improve east-west
mobility. Bridges are planned over the light rail alignment at both the I-25 & Broadway and Alameda
Stations. These will connect the DDD to development on the west side of the light rail tracks. The third
bridge is planned to span the Platte River on Bayaud Avenue which will connect the Baker neighborhood
to the Platte River Trail. In addition, a pedestrian/bicycle bridge over I-25 at Virginia Avenue is noted to
be considered as a long-range improvement in the Alameda Station TOD plan.

As improvements are made to the existing internal roadway facilities or as new internal roadways are
opened, sidewalks will be added to improve pedestrian circulation throughout the project site. An
extensive pedestrian sidewalk network is planned throughout the project to provide a quality pedestrian
environment connecting the development, parks, and transit access.

Bicycle Facilities
The pedestrian/bicycle bridges described above will enhance east-west bicycle access in the vicinity of
the project. In addition, a bicycle trail connecting the I-25 & Broadway and Alameda Stations, adjacent to
the tracks is planned for the near future.

The existing bicycle routes will continue to provide bicycle circulation around the DDD. On-street bicycle
lanes are recommended for Virginia Avenue between Cherokee Street and Broadway and on Cherokee
Street between the I-25 & Broadway and Alameda Stations or the addition of "sharrows" which indicate a
shared bicycle/ vehicle lane.




                                                                                                           47
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




8. Conclusions
This study was undertaken to analyze the impacts of the DDD as a part of the GDP process. The
following summarizes the results of this analysis:

    ·    AM and PM peak hour operations of 17 external and 6 internal intersections were evaluated for
         three conditions: existing, 2020, and 2030.

    ·    The existing analysis of the 17 external intersections shows that six of the study intersections
         currently operate below the LOS D threshold. Five of these intersections are side-street stop-
         control intersections where the side-street experiences significant delay trying to access or cross
         Broadway or Lincoln Street. Three of these intersections are slated to be upgraded to signals
         based on the Broadway NEPA study.

    ·    The future traffic analysis assumes that all improvements recommended in the Broadway NEPA
         study will be in place by 2020. Valley Highway improvements were not assumed to be in place for
         the 2020 nor 2030 analysis.

Phase 1 Analysis (2020)

    ·    In 2020, the DDD new development is expected to generate approximately 869 trips during the
         morning peak hour, 1,017 trips during the afternoon peak hour, and approximately 7,405 daily trips.
         These trips were added to the existing site generated trips for the traffic analysis as it was assumed
         that none of the existing development would be displaced in Phase 1.

    ·    The results of the 2020 analysis suggest that five of the external intersections are expected to
         operate below the LOS D threshold: Alameda Avenue & Kalamath Street, Alameda Avenue &
         Santa Fe Drive, Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street, Dakota Avenue & Lincoln Street, and Dakota
         Avenue & Broadway.

             o    The impact of the DDD development on the Alameda Avenue intersections in 2020 is
                  minor. Therefore, no mitigation measures are recommended for these intersections with
                  the completion of Phase 1 development. It is likely that these intersections will operate
                  near capacity with or without the DDD development until the Valley Highway EIS
                  improvements are in place.

             o    No mitigation measures are recommended for the Dakota Avenue intersections in 2020
                  as these intersections do no meet preliminary peak hour signal warrant analyses.

             o     In order to mitigate the Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street intersection to a LOS D, a third
                  westbound through lane would need to be added to the intersection. This would have
                  right-of-way and pedestrian environment impacts. Therefore, this mitigation measure is
                  not recommended.

             o    All of the internal intersections operate acceptably as side-street stop-control in 2020.




                                                                                                               48
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




Phase 2 Analysis (2030)

    ·    In 2030, the DDD new development is expected to generate approximately 3,299 trips during the
         morning peak hour, 3,525 trips during the afternoon peak hour, and approximately 26,523 daily
         trips. In addition, some of the existing vehicle trips were assumed to be displaced by the
         redevelopment which were credited in the analysis.

    ·    The results of the 2030 analysis indicate that thirteen intersections are expected to operate below
         the LOS D threshold. Mitigation measures are recommended for eleven of these intersections.
         With the implementation of the recommended mitigation measures, all of the study intersections
         except Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street are expected to operate at a LOS D or better during
         both peak hours in 2030.

             o    No mitigation measures are recommended for the Alameda Avenue & Lincoln Street
                  intersection due to the right-of-way, pedestrian, and transit impacts. This intersection
                  would best be addressed by Lincoln Street and Alameda Avenue corridor studies.

             o    Consistent with the Valley Highway EIS, it is recommended that a third westbound
                  through lane be added to both the Alameda Avenue & Kalamath Street and the Alameda
                  Avenue & Santa Fe Drive intersections.

             o    In order to accommodate additional traffic traveling to the project site, it is recommended
                  that the westbound left turn movement be converted from permitted only to
                  protected/permitted at the Alameda Avenue & Bannock Street intersection.

             o    Based on preliminary signal warrant analyses it is recommended that Dakota Avenue &
                  Lincoln Street and Dakota Avenue & Broadway be signalized upon completion of Phase
                  2 of the DDD and a full signal warrant analysis.

             o    Minor striping mitigation measures are recommended at the Virginia Avenue & Lincoln
                  Street, Center Avenue & Lincoln Street, and Center Avenue & Broadway intersections.
                  The striping changes are recommended on the side streets to provide dedicated turn
                  lanes onto Broadway or Lincoln Street as opposed to shared through/turn lanes.
                  Preliminary observations of all of these intersections suggest that these changes could
                  be made without acquiring additional right-of-way.

             o    The eastbound approach of Exposition Avenue & Broadway is expected to be
                  constructed with the development of Phase 2 of the DDD. It is recommended that this
                  leg of the intersection be constructed with two eastbound lanes, one thru lane and one a
                  dedicated right turn lane. In addition, it is recommended that striping be added to
                  Broadway at this location to separate the southbound left turn traffic from the through
                  traffic.

             o    Signals are recommended for two of the internal intersections along Bannock Street.
                  Dakota Avenue & Bannock Street and Virginia Avenue & Bannock Street should both be
                  converted to signals upon buildout of Phase 2 of the development as the projected
                  volumes are expected to be higher than can be accommodated with stop control.

    ·    Transit, bicycle, and pedestrian improvements are being planned in the vicinity of the DDD that are
         expected to improve multi-modal circulation within and around the project site. Dedicated bicycle
         lanes along Cherokee Avenue and Virginia Avenue are recommended or the addition of sharrows
         for the shared bicycle/ vehicle lanes.




                                                                                                             49
Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008

Denver Design District - Transportation Impact Study
November 2008




                                        Appendix D
    Sensitivity Analysis ­ 10/22/08 GDP
              Land Use Update
Sensitivity Analysis
Between the submittal of the Draft TIS and the Final TIS, the land use for the GDP area changed.
The full buildout of the project remained similar, but the horizon years 2020 and 2030 changed
slightly as additional market analysis has been completed. To determine the need to change all
of the analysis in the traffic study, a sensitivity analysis was completed to determine whether or
not the conclusions of the report would remain the same or change with the new land uses.

2020 Land Use and Trip Generation

The land uses and associated un-adjusted trip generation rates that were used for the Traffic
Study are as follow:

                                                     Daily             AM Peak Hour         PM Peak Hour
                         ITE
 Land Use               Code      Units     Trips      In      Out    Trips   In    Out   Trips   In    Out
 Residential            232     300 DU      1,254      627     627    102      20    83   114      70    43
 Regional Retail        820      31 KSF     3,172     1,586   1,586    32      19    12   289     139   150
 Neighborhood Retail    814      30 KSF     1,330      665     665    111      58    53    81      36    46
 Office                 710     769 KSF     6,417     3,209   3,209   959     844   115   940     160   780

 Total                                      12,172    6,086   6,086   1,204   940   263   1,424   405   1,019

The adjusted trips were as follows:

                        ITE

Neighborhood Retail     814      30 KSF     1,150     575      575     96      50   46      71     31    40
Office                  710     769 KSF     2,977    1,489    1,489   673     592   81     659    112    547


Total                                       7,405    3,703    3,703   869     670   199   1,017   293    724

contains less office than originally contemplated but retail is added with the addition of furniture
retail. The residential units are close to the number originally anticipated and the regional and
neighborhood retail remains the same. The following table shows the unadjusted land use and
trips:

2020 Analysis

As shown in the charts, the trips either are fairly consistent between the two land use scenarios or
the trips decrease except the 2020 PM Peak Hour trips out. The increase in the trips prompted
an analysis of the 2020 PM peak hour. The table below shows the results of the intersection
analysis with the new generated trips.

Notes:
      1   The Signalized intersection LOS and delay results are reported for the overall intersection. The unsignalized results are reported for the
          worst case approach, with the overal intersection results provided in parenthesis for informational purposes.
      2   The delay is reported as the average delay per vehicle in seconds.



As shown in the table, the change in the PM peak hour operations are minimal. The delay
changes for almost all intersections, but the LOS remains consistent except for the intersection of
Alameda and Cherokee and Alameda and Broadway. Even with the increase in delay, the LOS
remains acceptable which therefore will not change associated mitigation conclusions.

The new land use table associated with the October 2008 GDP Phase 2 of the development
contains fewer residential units, more regional and neighborhood retail, less office, fewer hotel
rooms, less educational space and a slight increase in furniture retail space. The following table
shows the unadjusted land use and trips:

           0
As shown in the charts, the generated trips for the new 2030 land use scenario are consistently
lower than the trips generated for the previous scenario. Therefore, an analysis of the
intersection LOS was not completed for the 2030 scenario.

Sensitivity Analysis Conclusions

The change in the 2020 PM Peak Hour trips resulted in further analysis of the intersection LOS.
Because the intersection LOS did not change significantly, no changes to the 2020 mitigation and
conclusions of the report are necessary.

The decrease in trips for the 2030 scenario indicates that further analysis is not necessary. The
mitigation for the 2030 scenario in the report remain valid.
